Question: A recession is typically defined as:
Option B: Two consecutive quarters of falling real GDP

Option B: Price level and total real output demanded
Option D: Price level and total real output supplied

Question: Short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) slopes upward primarily because:
Option A: All prices and wages are fully flexible
Option B: Some input prices, especially wages, are sticky in the short run

Question: Long-run aggregate supply (LRAS) is vertical because:
Option A: Real output depends only on price level
Option B: Wages are sticky in the long run
Option C: Real output depends on resources and technology, not price level
Option D: Demand is constant in the long run

Question: A recessionary (negative) output gap occurs when:
Option A: Actual real GDP exceeds potential GDP
Option B: Actual real GDP equals potential GDP
Option C: Actual real GDP is below potential GDP
Option D: Unemployment is below the natural rate

Question: An inflationary (positive) output gap occurs when:
Option A: Actual GDP is below potential GDP
Option C: Actual GDP is above potential GDP
Option D: Unemployment is above the natural rate

Question: The marginal propensity to consume (MPC) is defined as:
Option B: Change in consumption / change in income
Option C: Change in saving / change in income
Option E: Change in income / change in consumption
